book_title: The Figure Page Object: Structuring Visual Data in Documents
overall_summary: By the end readers will not only understand the components of a robust Figure object but will also be able to craft figures that are semantically rich, machine-readable, and human-friendly. The book positions the Figure object as a pattern for improving clarity, reproducibility, and utility of visual content in technical documentation and data-driven reports.
key_themes: Interoperability between human-readable captions and machine-readable data
Clear metadata schemas for figures and charts
Data-to-visual mapping and visual encoding choices
Annotations, footnotes, and provenance for context and reproducibility
learning_objectives: Understand the concept of a page object and why formalizing figures matters
Identify and populate essential figure metadata fields (title, type, keywords, description, summary, data table, axis titles, footnotes)
Translate a visual (e.g., bar chart) into a machine-friendly data table and back into a human caption
Apply color encoding and categorical grouping intentionally to convey meaning
Add annotations and footnotes that improve interpretability and maintain provenance

chapter_summaries.summary: This chapter drills into the 'Figure' page object introduced earlier in the book, moving from the conceptual idea of page objects and document structure to a concrete example: a bar chart representing monthly business values from January to June. It enumerates the figure's metadata fields (Title, ChartType, TopicKeywords, DetailedDescription, Summary, MarkdownDataTable, AxisTitles, FootnotesAndAnnotations) and shows how those fields map to both a human-readable caption and a machine-friendly data table. The example bar chart has values [200, 300, 400, 450, 350, 250], peaks in April (450) and bottoms in January (200), and uses color coding to group months (orange: Jan/Apr, green: Feb/May, blue: Mar/Jun).
